div.l: Yit has my felaw sum what for his harme
He has the Milner doughtir in his arme
He auntrid him and has his nede spedde
And I ligge as a draf sacke in my bedde
And when this layke is teld anoþir day
I mon̄ be hald a daffid cokenay
I wil rise and auntre me be my faith
Vnhardy vnceli thus me saith
And up he roos and furth he went
Vnto the cradle and in his Armes it hent
And bare it soft vnto his beddis feet
And sone aft̉ir the wif hir routyng lete
And gan to wake and went hir͗e vnto pisse
And cam̄ ayen̄ and gan hir cradle mysse
And gropid higher but ther͗e she found none
Alas coth she I had almost mys gone
I had almost gone to the clerkis bedde
Ey bn̄enedicite than had I foule spedde
And furth she goth til she the cradil fond
She gropith alwey further with hir hond
And found the bedde and thought not but good
Bicause that the cradil by it stood
And wist not wher͗e she was for it was derk
But feir͗e and wel she crepith vnto the clerk
And lith ful stille and hath caught a slepe
Withyn̄ a while this Iohn this clerc up lepe
And on this wif he leith on̄ ful sore
So mery a nyght hadde she not to fore
He prikid hard and fast as he wer͗e madde
This ioly lif han thees two clerkis hadde
Til that the third cok began̄ to singe
Aleyn wax wery in the dawnyng
For he had swonken̄ al the long nyght
And seid farwel malyn̄ my swete wight
The day is comen I may no lenger abide
But euermore wher͗e euer so I go or ride
I am thine ovne clerc so haue I w hele
Now dere leman̄ coth she farwele
But or thou go one thing I wil the telle
Whan that thou goist home by the mille
Right at the entre of the dore behinde
Thou shalt a cake of half a busshel finde
That was y made of thyn̄ ovne mele
Which that I halp myselue forto stele
